page.title: 11TOLMERS NATIONAL SCOUT CAMP.
page.content: The land for Tolmers Scout Camp was first bought in 1939, at the beginning of the Second World War. There are 70 acres of pasture, and 30 acres of woodland. During the war, farmers moved onto the land, and used it for growing their crops. At the end of the war the Scout Association had a very hard job getting back the land, which still belonged to them. When the railway to Hertford was built, the bricks that were used for building Ponsbourne Tunnel were made on the site. There are still some remains of the kilns in the North-East corner of the site.When they dug away the earth from the slope, the sides of the track were left with gaps in them. This made them unsafe, so some Victorian rubbish dumps from Islington were brought out to fill in the holes.Some interesting 'treasures' have been found here.
